articles.headline: Facebook to Require Verified Identities for Future Political Ads
articles.snippet: As Mark Zuckerberg, the company’s chief executive, prepares to testify before Congress, the company also said it supported the proposed Honest Ads Act.
articles.abstract: As Mark Zuckerberg, the company’s chief executive, prepares to testify before Congress, the company also said it supported the proposed Honest Ads Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For months, Facebook’s critics — ranging from Silicon Valley executives to Washington politicians — have been urging the company to do a better job of identifying who is buying political ads and creating pages about hot-button topics on its social media sites.

articles.headline: Kenya Barris, Creator of ‘Black-ish,’ Is Said to Seek an Exit From ABC
articles.snippet: More than a month after the network pulled a charged episode of his show, the producer is looking to leave for Netflix, people familiar with negotiations said.
articles.abstract: More than a month after the network pulled a charged episode of his show, the producer is looking to leave for Netflix, people familiar with negotiations said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kenya Barris, the A-list writer-producer behind the ABC comedy “black-ish,” has grown frustrated with his home network and is examining the possibility of making an early exit from his contract, according to three people familiar with the negotiations.
articles.byline: By John Koblin and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Oprah, Rupert Murdoch, Harvard: Saudi Prince’s U.S. Tour
articles.snippet: The heir to Saudi Arabia’s throne has been on an extraordinary tour of the United States, seeking investment and trying to change perceptions of the opaque, conservative kingdom.
articles.abstract: The heir to Saudi Arabia’s throne has been on an extraordinary tour of the United States, seeking investment and trying to change perceptions of the opaque, conservative kingdom.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — He talked about the movie business with Michael Douglas, Morgan Freeman and Dwayne Johnson over dinner at Rupert Murdoch’s house. He discussed space travel with Richard Branson in the California desert, and philanthropy with Bill Gates and technology with Jeff Bezos in Seattle. He visited Harvard and MIT, brokered arms deals with President Trump and sat down with Wall Street financiers. He even met with Oprah Winfrey.

articles.headline: A $350 Million Fund Helps Many Public Servants. Meet the Ones Left Out.
articles.snippet: Congress created a fix-it fund for borrowers in the public service loan forgiveness plan. Many categories of educators, lawyers and others are ineligible.
articles.abstract: Congress created a fix-it fund for borrowers in the public service loan forgiveness plan. Many categories of educators, lawyers and others are ineligible.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, Congress created a $350 million pot of money to help teachers, firefighters and others in public service who thought they were enrolled in a program that would forgive their student loans after 10 years of payments. Many of them were not getting credit for their loan payments after all.

articles.headline: More Jobs, Faster Growth and Now, the Threat of a Trade War
articles.snippet: In his inaugural speech, the new Fed chairman tried to focus on the strength of the economy even as a spiraling tariff battle with China spooked investors.
articles.abstract: In his inaugural speech, the new Fed chairman tried to focus on the strength of the economy even as a spiraling tariff battle with China spooked investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The rapidly escalating trade conflict with China has upended the prevailing economic dynamic of falling unemployment and faster growth, leaving policymakers and investors scrambling to figure out the way forward.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: ‘Big Brother’ in India Requires Fingerprint Scans for Food, Phones and Finances
articles.snippet: The government requires its people to submit finger, eye and facial images. The ID is mandatory for many services, but opponents say it infringes privacy.
articles.abstract: The government requires its people to submit finger, eye and facial images. The ID is mandatory for many services, but opponents say it infringes privacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Seeking to build an identification system of unprecedented scope, India is scanning the fingerprints, eyes and faces of its 1.3 billion residents and connecting the data to everything from welfare benefits to mobile phones.

articles.headline: The Disappearing Doctor: How Mega-Mergers Are Changing the Business of Medical Care
articles.snippet: Big corporations — giant retailers and health insurance companies — are teaming up to become your doctor.
articles.abstract: Big corporations — giant retailers and health insurance companies — are teaming up to become your doctor.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is the doctor in?
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Farmers’ Anger at Trump Tariffs Puts Republican Candidates in a Bind
articles.snippet: President Trump is moving to fulfill one of his central campaign promises, but a get-tough stance with China could reverberate badly in the nation’s heartland.
articles.abstract: President Trump is moving to fulfill one of his central campaign promises, but a get-tough stance with China could reverberate badly in the nation’s heartland.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Trump moves to fulfill one of the central promises of his campaign — to get tough on an ascendant China — he faces a potential rebellion from a core constituency: farmers and other agricultural producers who could suffer devastating losses in a trade war.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: Ex-President ‘Lula’ of Brazil Surrenders to Serve 12-Year Jail Term
articles.snippet: The imprisonment of the former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva was a remarkable fall for a statesman who transformed Brazil — and who was leading in the polls for October’s presidential election.
articles.abstract: The imprisonment of the former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva was a remarkable fall for a statesman who transformed Brazil — and who was leading in the polls for October’s presidential election.
articles.lead_paragraph: CURITIBA, Brazil — After vowing for months that a conviction on corruption charges would not stand in the way of his bid for a third term as Brazil’s leader, former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva surrendered to the police on Saturday evening to begin serving a 12-year sentence.
articles.byline: By Manuela Andreoni, Ernesto Londoño and Shasta Darlington

articles.headline: Denver Post Rebels Against Its Hedge-Fund Ownership
articles.snippet: Facing the loss of more than two dozen newsroom jobs, the beleaguered newspaper is printing an editorial blasting Alden Global Capital: “We call for action.”
articles.abstract: Facing the loss of more than two dozen newsroom jobs, the beleaguered newspaper is printing an editorial blasting Alden Global Capital: “We call for action.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The Denver Post is in open revolt against its owner.

articles.headline: Republicans Seize on Impeachment for Edge in 2018 Midterms
articles.snippet: Invoking the specter of President Trump’s impeachment has become a fund-raising and get-out-the-vote tactic for Republicans. Democratic leaders see the issue as a trap.
articles.abstract: Invoking the specter of President Trump’s impeachment has become a fund-raising and get-out-the-vote tactic for Republicans. Democratic leaders see the issue as a trap.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Republican leaders scramble to stave off a Democratic wave or at least mitigate their party’s losses in November, a strategy is emerging on the right for how to energize conservatives and drive a wedge between the anti-Trump left and moderate voters: warn that Democrats will immediately move to impeach President Trump if they capture the House.

articles.headline: Dozens Suffocate in Syria as Government Is Accused of Chemical Attack
articles.snippet: President Trump denounced the attack that killed at least 42 people and that left hundreds with “symptoms indicative of exposure to a chemical agent,” according to aid groups.
articles.abstract: President Trump denounced the attack that killed at least 42 people and that left hundreds with “symptoms indicative of exposure to a chemical agent,” according to aid groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Dozens of Syrians choked to death after a suspected chemical attack struck the rebel-held suburb of Douma, east of Damascus, with aid groups on Sunday blaming President Bashar al-Assad’s government for the assault and Western governments expressing outrage.

articles.headline: Facebook’s Other Critics: Its Viral Stars
articles.snippet: As Facebook reels from a privacy scandal, some of its most popular users are lashing out over declining traffic, policy changes and financial complaints.
articles.abstract: As Facebook reels from a privacy scandal, some of its most popular users are lashing out over declining traffic, policy changes and financial complaints.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the past two years, Ryan Hamilton has been getting Facebook-famous. Mr. Hamilton, 28, manages a network of Facebook pages and makes viral videos for his “Hammy T.V.” channel — mostly lowbrow fare with titles like “Shocking Pit Bull Social Experiment” and “World’s Hottest Pepper on Girlfriend’s Thong” — that have earned him a level of popularity typically associated with Kardashians and BuzzFeed food clips.

articles.headline: Credit Card Signatures Are About to Become Extinct in the U.S.
articles.snippet: The major credit card networks are ending a requirement that people sign for most card transactions — the latest blow to the signature.
articles.abstract: The major credit card networks are ending a requirement that people sign for most card transactions — the latest blow to the signature.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nearly a decade, Doug Taylor, a sales manager who travels often for work, has signed credit card receipts with a doodle of a dog wagging its tail.

articles.headline: Deutsche Bank Replaces C.E.O. Amid Losses and Lack of Direction
articles.snippet: Christian Sewing, who has spent most of his career at the German bank, will replace John Cryan. Mr. Cryan was criticized for moving too slowly to cut costs.
articles.abstract: Christian Sewing, who has spent most of his career at the German bank, will replace John Cryan. Mr. Cryan was criticized for moving too slowly to cut costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The banking crisis that began in 2008 seems like ancient history in much of the world, but not at Deutsche Bank. Never-ending turmoil at the bank — Germany’s largest lender — including three straight years of losses, a plunging share price, and a troubled investment bank, cost its chief executive his job on Sunday.

articles.headline: As Trump Seeks Way Out of Syria, New Attack Pulls Him Back In
articles.snippet: A reported chemical attack on a Damascus suburb seems to raise the political and military stakes as President Trump charts the United States’ future in Syria.
articles.abstract: A reported chemical attack on a Damascus suburb seems to raise the political and military stakes as President Trump charts the United States’ future in Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Days after President Trump said he wanted to pull the United States out of Syria, Syrian forces hit a suburb of Damascus with bombs that rescue workers said unleashed toxic gas.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: ‘You Are the Product’: Targeted by Cambridge Analytica on Facebook
articles.snippet: Facebook plans to begin notifying users on Monday who were affected by Cambridge Analytica’s data collection. The Times has already spoken with some people whose data was taken.
articles.abstract: Facebook plans to begin notifying users on Monday who were affected by Cambridge Analytica’s data collection. The Times has already spoken with some people whose data was taken.
articles.lead_paragraph: Christopher Deason stumbled upon the psychological questionnaire on June 9, 2014. He was taking a lot of online surveys back then, each one earning him a few dollars to help pay the bills. Nothing about this one, which he saw on an online job platform, struck him as “creepy or weird,” he said later.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Gabriel J.X. Dance

articles.headline: In John Bolton, Trump Finds a Fellow Political Blowtorch. Will Foreign Policy Burn?
articles.snippet: Mr. Bolton takes over as the president’s third national security adviser Monday. In a world of carrot-and-stick diplomacy, Mr. Bolton is a stick man: “I don’t do carrots.”
articles.abstract: Mr. Bolton takes over as the president’s third national security adviser Monday. In a world of carrot-and-stick diplomacy, Mr. Bolton is a stick man: “I don’t do carrots.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Shortly after Ambassador John R. Bolton was sent to represent the United States at the United Nations, an institution he had long scorned as an anti-American citadel of corruption, he hosted President George W. Bush for a visit.

articles.headline: Nordstrom Opening a New York Store as Other Retailers Close Theirs
articles.snippet: Need a tie at 2 a.m.? Order it online, and a men’s store employee will meet you at the entrance. It’s part of Nordstrom’s bet that flagship stores have a future.
articles.abstract: Need a tie at 2 a.m.? Order it online, and a men’s store employee will meet you at the entrance. It’s part of Nordstrom’s bet that flagship stores have a future.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Nordstrom family has run stores for more than a century, first selling shoes in the Pacific Northwest and later introducing fashion-forward clothing to wealthy suburbanites across the country.

articles.headline: A Town That Lives for Hockey Is Devastated by Humboldt Broncos’ Deaths
articles.snippet: Even by Canadian standards, Humboldt’s passion for hockey stands out. The deaths of 15 players and personnel in a bus accident has shattered the small town and resonated across Canada.
articles.abstract: Even by Canadian standards, Humboldt’s passion for hockey stands out. The deaths of 15 players and personnel in a bus accident has shattered the small town and resonated across Canada.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUMBOLDT, Saskatchewan — Update: An earlier version of this article, relying on incorrect information from the Office of the Chief Coroner of Saskatchewan, misidentified one of the victims killed in the crash. He was Parker Tobin, not Xavier Labelle.

articles.headline: Iran-Israel Conflict Escalates in Shadow of Syrian Civil War
articles.snippet: Airstrikes on a Syrian military base killed four Iranian advisers, part of the Iranian military presence in Syria that Israel is trying to block.
articles.abstract: Airstrikes on a Syrian military base killed four Iranian advisers, part of the Iranian military presence in Syria that Israel is trying to block.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Israel on Monday appeared to have escalated its shadow war in Syria against Iran, with a predawn airstrike against a military base that coordinates Iranian-backed militias, killing four Iranian military advisers.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and David M. Halbfinger

articles.headline: After Chemical Weapons Attack in Syria, Trump Weighs Retaliation
articles.snippet: The president said Syria’s patrons in Russia and Iran may also be responsible for enabling last weekend’s chemical attack. “Everybody’s going to pay a price,” he said.
articles.abstract: The president said Syria’s patrons in Russia and Iran may also be responsible for enabling last weekend’s chemical attack. “Everybody’s going to pay a price,” he said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said Monday that he might seek to hold accountable not just Syria but its patrons in Russia and Iran for a chemical weapons attack that killed dozens of people outside Damascus over the weekend, a move that could widen a geopolitical conflict already roiling the Middle East.
